title: Linking up the web of data
displayTitle: Linking up the web of data
body:
The current web is primarily configured as a series of documents. While these documents draw on rich sources of data, they disguise it beneath pages designed for humans to view. In this module, we explore what would happen if you remove these human-friendly documents from the web. Imagine you only had the data, all open, all usable and all interlinked in a big network or 'web' of data.

In this module we introduce the web of open linked data and look at how the 5-Stars of linked open data can help us get there.

In this module we’ll look at:
  • What is the web of data?
  • Web identifiers for physical things
  • Creating a deeply connected web of open linked data

title: Surfing the web of data – in 2 minutes
displayTitle: Surfing the web of data – in 2 minutes
body: The ODI’s David Tarrant introduces athe web of linked open data and examines how the 5-stars of open linked data can help you start surfing the web of data

title: Understanding the web of data
body: The web of linked open data is changing the way we access and browse open data.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: What is the web of data?
_items.body:
Think of the current web as a series of documents. These documents are designed (by people) to be visually attractive (for other people) to read and to provide them with information. What these documents are not designed for is to present raw data in a way that both humans and machines can read.

There is a significant difference between data that is ‘on the web’ and the ‘web of data’. Data “‘on the web’ is a file that you download from a document. The web of data is a set of deeply-linked data resources that can be instantly read and understood by both humans and machines.

_graphic.title: What os the web of data?

_items.title: Linking up the web of data
_items.body:
In order to further explore this concept, imagine that the visually-attractive documents were stripped away from the web. How would you find your way around?

You would need signposts to tell you how your current location relates to others around it.

The “web of linked open data” provides just these signposts by requiring that all data be connected via links to other data. These links allow not just you to navigate between data points but, crucially, also allow machines to do so.

_graphic.alt: Linking up the web of data
_graphic.title: Linking up the web of data

_items.title: What can a web of linked open data do?
_items.body:
We don’t need to imagine what it would be like to navigate the web of data as some parts of it already exists and are deeply connected.

Large corporations like Microsoft have even researched tools that would allow us to navigate this web in a whole new way

title: Building a web of data
body:
In order to build a web of open linked data we need two things:

  • Data that can be referenced on the web
  • People to reference this data from within their own data

These are the two conditions that meet the requirements of the 4th and 5th starts of linked open data.

title: 4th star: open identifiers
body: The 4th star is all about being able to reference things on the web.

_items.title: Open identifiers
_items.body:
An identifier is simply a short way of referencing a more complex thing. ISBNs for books and Zip/Postal codes for places are common examples. However, there are huge amount of other identifiers used both by the public and private sector.

The problem is that we rely on search engines to tell us more about what these identifiers are for. Web based identifiers don’t have this problem as you can simply click the identifier to find out more.

To look at an example, the ISBN number for a specific book is 9781568848624. To find the book using this ISBN, you would have to type it into a search engine before you could find the results. By contrast the web-based identifer for the same book can be followed direct from any web browser http://bookshop.blackwell.co.uk/jsp/id/Netscape_and_the_World_Wide_Web_For_Dummies/9781568848624

_items.title: Using the 4th star
_items.body:
The 4th star requires the creation or use of identifiers for things, both physical and digital.

This identifier is for the physical thing itself. An ISBN references a physical book, a web based identifier for the book is no different it references the book and not a web page about the book.

Thus a 3D printer could use a web based identifier in order to get data in order to print a physical thing.

_items.title: 4th star open data
_items.body:
The 4th star also requires that if a user clicks on a link and cannot be provided with the exact thing (book, object, person, building) that they be provided with some contextual information about that thing.

This is often done by redirecting the client (human or machine) to a suitable representation of this thing for them. This suitable representation might be a web page, or raw data under that web page.

_items.title: Try it out...
_items.body:
Some web based identifiers arecool

A cool URI means that you can tell what the identifier is for before you even click it. Before you click the ones below try and guess what they are for:

http://data.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/id/postcodeunit/SO171BJ

Note that the page you get back when you click will have a different address. You asked the server for a physical thing and it sent you to a web page about it as that is what your browser asked for usingcontent negotiation

Why not try adding extensions like “.json” and “.rdf” and seeing what happens or even trying your hand at content negotiation?

title: 5th star: linked data
body: The 5th star is all about linking things together

_items.title: The link
_items.body:
The 5th star simply introduces the concept of linking things together.

These links enable humans and machines to navigate between data sources on the web.

Linking also allows you to direct the person or machine to authoritative data on things, like we do on the web, rather than storing a local copy of data that will soon be out of date.

_items.title: Using the 5th star
_items.body:
Think of database of buildings that a company owns. It will often have Postcodes/Zip codes against each building in the data records:
Building name: EEE Building
Building number: 32
Building postcode: SO17 1BJ

Ad linked data:

Building name: EEE Building
Building number: 32
Building postcode:http://data.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/id/postcodeunit/SO171BJ

_items.title: Try it out...
_items.body:
You may have already seen some links in the data that we explored last time.

Why not try these two links which load the same data from before into a data browser. The data browser content negotiates for data (not a web page) and displays the raw data in a human readable form.

Everything in red in the browser is a link in the data which hopefully goes to more data.

See what you can discover in the web of linked open data.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006q2x0

title: Are you ready for surfing the web of data?
displayTitle: Are you ready for surfing the web of data?
body: There are four helpful things to remember when thinking about surfing the web of linked open data, can you recall them?

title: What is the web of data?
displayTitle: What is the web of data?

_items.text: A web of data portals where you can download data

title: Which of these are identifiers for the band One Direction?
displayTitle: Which of these are identifiers for the band One Direction?
instruction: Select up to 3 options, then click Submit.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

They all are! The first two use the same sub identifier but are different authorities. The third one is the wikipedia identifier (dbpedia) for the artist. They all link to each other and share each others data, can you find the links?

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

In fact all three are identifiers. The first two use the same sub identifier but are different authorities. The third one is the wikipedia identifier (dbpedia) for the artist. They all link to each other and share each others data, can you find the links?

title: Surfing the web of linked open data
displayTitle: Surfing the web of linked open data
body:
The web of data is a set of deeply-linked data resources that can be instantly read and understood by both humans and machines.

In 1989, Tim Berners-Lee invented the web of documents and it took us 20+ years to work out how to use it. It is now a fundamental part of our society. In 2001, Tim envisioned the web of linked open data and we are still realising how this is going to fundamentally change the web all over again.
